comment.author: 39191857@N05
comment._content: Are you surprised?  Those are "iron lungs" of Guinness and there was carousing for months afterwards and the journo's were the leaders in the field!  Seriously it really is a surprise that there is no mention in the papers, big event then and now!
comment.authorname: swordscookie

comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/swordscookie] That's what I would have thought, but I tried a range of wide and narrow search terms and came up empty! Are you being poetic, or is/was "iron lungs" a nickname for the Guinness barrels?
comment.authorname: National Library of Ireland on The Commons

comment.author: 39191857@N05
comment._content: When they changed over to aluminium from wood there were a number of stories in the news of people who were being kept alive in "iron lungs" which did the breathing for them and so the metal kegs became known as "iron lungs as a result.  I see that master of research blackpoolbeach has come up with more information on the incident including some of your photographs!
comment.authorname: swordscookie

comment.author: 22919290@N08
comment._content: Excellent photo, just look at all those beer kegs! I suspect the train had a few oil tank wagons which the larger road tanker is recovering their contents. This is the location today, the signal cabin in the picture was in situ until about 10 years ago. If I get a chance I'll look up the old IRRS journals for this accident.

comment.author: 22919290@N08
comment._content: Crash at 46 Mile Box 'On 12th February a number of wagons on the 19:30 goods (Sligo - ex North Wall) were derailed. They piled up just on the Mullingar side of the signal cabin completely blocking the line. It appears that a wagon in the middle of the train was derailed some distance on the Dublin side of the cabin and that the following wagons came off the road at the level crossing. Trains were diverted via Portarlington and buses were called in until the following evening, when the siding was slewed into the running line to allow trains to pass the accident scene. Loco A44r went down with the Inchicore crane, leaving North Wall around 3:00 on the 13th. A51r attended with 2M, the Athlone crane. Three oil tankers - nos. 1720, 1726 and 1732 had run down the embankment on the down side and two were upside down in a stream. The line was eventually cleared by the evening of the 14th, when A44r etc.. returned to Dublin around 21:00.' Irish Railway News (May, 1971, Vol 17/2)
comment.authorname: Flying Snail

comment.author: 14302637@N08
